answers.author: Evelina Moulder
answers.text:
Dear Mr. Patterson,
We conducted a survey about food security not long ago that included a question about urban agriculture. In Wyoming, the cities of Laramie, Douglas, Cody, and Worland reported policies allowing chickens, bees, etc., in residential areas.
Best,

answers.text:
Hello John, 
Various similar questions have been asked in the past.  Most of them relate to chickens on urban properties:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/questions/kn/Question/22385/Chickens_in_urban_areas
Answers to that question have a variety of resources attached.  Another similar question included an examination of animal ordinances from 25 cities:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/questions/kn/Question/20130/Does_your_local_government_have_an_ordinance_permitting_chickens_on_residential_property
This is an Animal and Fowl ordinance from Washoe County which might serve as a reference ordinance:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/4824/Animal_and_Fowl_Ordinance
It's worth mentioning that there can be legal issues in such ordinances.  The Rutherford Institute, a civil liberties organization, has sought to protect homeowners from citations:
https://www.rutherford.org/publications_resources/on_the_front_lines/rutherford_institute_defends_homeowner_charged_criminally_with_violating_ci
I hope these resources help you learn about comprehensive animal ordinances.
Gabe Brehm
Knowledge Network Intern
ICMA

Hi John, here is a link to El Cerrito's Municipal Code Title 7, Animals: http://library.municode.com/HTML/16333/level1/TIT7AN.html#TOPTITLE.  Chapter 7.08 addresses bees, chickens, pigs, goats, etc.  It was the result of an extensive public process.  Feel free to email me directly at kpinkos@ci.el-cerrito.ca.us if you have specific questions.  --Karen
